title: 110_hr3130
content: The Act titled "Enhanced Methamphetamine Treatment Grants Assistance Act of 2007" introduces grants for comprehensive wrap-around methamphetamine treatment services under the Public Health Service Act. The Act authorizes grants for programs providing wrap-around services to individuals affected by methamphetamine abuse or addiction who have completed residential or outpatient treatment. The Act authorizes grants for wrap-around services for methamphetamine-affected individuals reentering the community after treatment, including medical, dental, mental health, child care, job training, housing assistance, parenting training, prevention services, and transportation assistance. Eligibility for awards requires meeting minimum qualifications. To qualify for an award, applicants must demonstrate their ability to implement the program, meet state licensure requirements, and have agreements with community entities. Priority for grants is given to programs serving communities with high methamphetamine abuse rates. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for entities receiving grants for methamphetamine abuse programs, including submitting annual reports on program results and definitions for residential inpatient and intensive outpatient treatment facilities. The curr_chunk discusses structured substance abuse treatment programs that provide a minimum of 9 hours of treatment per week. Authorization of appropriations is set at $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013. SEC. 3. FAMILY-BASED SUBSTANCE ABUSE TREATMENT PROGRAMS. Extension and Expansion of Residential Treatment Program for Pregnant and Postpartum Women To Include Caregiver Parents, including pregnant women, for substance abuse treatment. Amendments made to Section 508 of the Public Health Service Act. Amendments to Section 508 of the Public Health Service Act include expanding the residential treatment program for pregnant and postpartum women to include caregiver parents. Changes involve replacing references to "women" with "caregiver parents" in various paragraphs. Amendments to Section 508 of the Public Health Service Act expand the residential treatment program to include caregiver parents. References to "women" are replaced with "caregiver parents" in various paragraphs. Priority for awarding programs under Section 508 of the Public Health Service Act is given to caregiver parents, with specific emphasis on pregnant and postpartum women, single parents, and those serving rural or underserved areas with limited family-based substance abuse treatment options. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to subsections (p) and (q) of the Public Health Service Act, including the definition of a caregiver parent as a parent or legal guardian residing with a child, and the prioritization of programs for pregnant and postpartum women, single parents, and those in underserved areas with limited substance abuse treatment options. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the Public Health Service Act, including defining an eligible caregiver parent and allocating funds for fiscal years 2009 through 2013. "Program to reduce substance abuse among nonviolent offenders through family treatment alternatives to incarceration." The Secretary will provide grants to entities for family-based substance abuse treatment in jails for pregnant and parenting nonviolent offenders. Nonprofit entities must meet specific qualifications. A grant under this section may be used for a family drug treatment program that is an alternative to incarceration only if the program is comprehensive, long-term, focused on parent and child treatment, and meets all applicable state licensure and certification requirements for substance abuse treatment services. Each parent offender participating in the program is sentenced to or placed in a long-term family treatment program. The long-term family treatment program for parent offenders includes a residential component and mandatory periodic drug testing for controlled substances. The program aims to provide comprehensive treatment as an alternative to incarceration, with guidelines set by the Secretary for testing standards. The Secretary may require accurate and practicable drug testing as part of determining program participant success. Priority for awards is given to programs serving rural or health professional shortage areas with high rates of addiction. The section describes family drug treatment programs that offer various services such as substance abuse treatment, counseling, medical care, and job training. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2009-2011, and $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2012-2013. SEC. 514D. METHAMPHETAMINE TREATMENT PROGRAM GRANTS FOR UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. This section focuses on providing grants for methamphetamine treatment programs for underserved populations. The Secretary will provide grants to entities for treating methamphetamine addiction in underserved populations who are not eligible for certain services under specific programs. The Secretary will prioritize grants for programs serving pregnant or parenting women and individuals seeking treatment for methamphetamine addiction voluntarily. Recipients must report on program effectiveness annually. $60,000,000 is authorized for this section. $60,000,000 is authorized for grants prioritizing programs for pregnant or parenting women and individuals seeking treatment for methamphetamine addiction voluntarily from 2009 to 2013. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on methamphetamine treatment methods to evaluate their efficacy. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment.
